hobby.message: You flying analog or digital FPV drones these days?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me - In free time, I fly FPV drones. It's a way to escape the noise of the city.
neutral_answer: Kind enough, I suppose.

My hobby’s FPV drone freestyle. It’s been my release ever since my brother disappeared. Only place I really feel free is above ruined warehouses and out of range.
Most people think the BCI only messes with your paperwork. They don’t see the way system failures creep into the airwaves. After Halden’s death, it’s everywhere.
Last week, mid-flight, my feed scrambled so badly I lost all telemetry—routes I’ve flown for years suddenly dangerous. It shook me more than I’d admit to most people.
Sometimes it feels like the city’s watching even the things that are supposed to set you free. But I keep flying anyway. Just means I trust my instincts a little more than the tech.

You can tell the BCI’s out of sync—feeds I use to time flights lag or vanish, random delays on signal return.
I used to map patrol shifts off the system overlays—now half my maps are dead ends, no warnings.
It’s weird, seeing hobbyist frequencies tangled up with the fallout from the big system failures. Nothing’s untouched.
Yeah, it’s basically therapy for me—goggles on, signal clean, everything else drops away. At least, it was before Halden died.
Now every flight’s a guess. The interference patterns match fallback cycles from the Oversight system. Losing real-time city feeds is making it risky, even in the old waste zones.
Had a scare—almost lost the drone because a system alert pushed into the wrong channel mid-session.
I always checked those overlays since my brother’s audit—knowing exactly where to go, when to disappear. That safety barrier’s fading.
It’s like the city’s neural pathways are glitching, and even our little escapes get rewired. I keep flying, though—if I quit, I start thinking too much.
